class tmlib.cfg.UserConfiguration(experiment_dir, cfg_settings)[source]¶

Bases: object

Class for experiment-specific configuration settings provided by the user.

PERSISTENT_ATTRS = set(['layers_dir', 'sources_dir', 'plates_dir', 'plate_format', 'workflow'])¶
layers_dir¶
Returns:absolute path to the directory where image pyramids and associated data are stored
Return type:str

Note

Defaults to “layers” subdirectory of the experiment directory if not set.

See also

`tmlib.illuminati.layers`_ `tmlib.jterator.data_fusion`_

Returns:plate format, i.e. total number of wells per plate
Return type:int

Returns:absolute path to the directory where extracted files are located (grouped per plate and cycle)
Return type:str

Note

Defaults to “plates” subdirectory of the experiment directory if not set.

See also

`tmlib.plate.Plate`_ `tmlib.cycle.Cycle`_

Return type:str

Note

Defaults to “sources” subdirectory of the experiment directory if not set.

See also

`tmlib.source.PlateSource`_ `tmlib.source.PlateAcquisition`_

Return type:List[WorkflowStepArgs]

See also

`tmaps.workflow.WorkflowStepArgs`_

tmlib.cfg.logger = <logging.Logger object>¶

Configuration settings constants:

Describe the experimental layout (directory structure and filename nomenclature) by Python format strings. The fieldnames are replaced by the program with the values of configuration class attributes.

tmlib.cfg_setters module¶

tmlib.cli module¶

class tmlib.cli.CommandLineInterface(args)[source]¶

Bases: object

Abstract base class for command line interfaces.

Note

There must be a method for each subparser, where the name of the method has to match the name of the corresponding subparser.

apply()[source]¶

Initialize an instance of the API class corresponding to the program and process arguments of the “apply” subparser.

call(args)[source]¶

Handler function that can be called by a subparser.

Initializes an instance of the class and calls the method matching the name of the specified subparser with the parsed arguments.

Parameters:args (argparse.Namespace) – parsed command line arguments

Note

args must have the attribute “subparser_name”, which specifies the name of the subparser.

cfg¶
Returns:configuration settings
Return type:Dict[str, str]
cleanup()[source]¶

Initialize an instance of the API class corresponding to the program and process arguments of the “cleanup” subparser.

collect()[source]¶

Initialize an instance of the API class corresponding to the program and process arguments of the “collect” subparser.

expected_outputs¶

Read the job descriptions and extract the “outputs” information.

Returns:absolute paths to outputs that should be generated by the program
Return type:List[str]
static get_parser_and_subparsers(required_subparsers=['init', 'run', 'submit', 'cleanup'])[source]¶

Get an argument parser object and subparser objects with default arguments for use in command line interfaces. The subparsers objects can be extended with additional subparsers and additional arguments can be added to each individual subparser.

Parameters:
  • required_subparsers (List[str]) – subparsers that should be returned (defaults to ["init", "run", "submit"])
  • level (str) – level of the directory tree at which the command line interface operates; “cycle” when processing data at the level of an individual cycle folder or “experiment” when processing data at the level of the experiment folder, i.e. across multiple cycle folders
Returns:

parser and subparsers objects
Return type:

Tuple[argparse.Argumentparser and argparse._SubParsersAction]

tmlib.cli.command_line_call(parser)[source]¶

Main entry point for command line interfaces.

Parsers the command line arguments to the corresponding handler and configures logging.

Parameters:parser (argparse.ArgumentParser) – argument parser object

Warning

Don’t do any other logging configuration anywhere else!

create_job_descriptions(**kwargs)[source]¶

Create job descriptions with information required for the creation and processing of individual jobs.

There are two kinds of jobs: * run jobs: tasks that are processed in parallel * collect job: a single task that is processed after run jobs

are terminated, i.e. successfully completed

Each batch (element of the run job_descriptions) must provide the following key-value pairs: * “id”: one-based job indentifier number (int) * “inputs”: absolute paths to input files required to run the job

(Dict[str, List[str]])
  • “outputs”: absolute paths to output files produced the job (Dict[str, List[str]])

In case a collect job is required, the corresponding batch must provide the following key-value pairs: * “inputs”: absolute paths to input files required to collect job

output of the run step (Dict[str, List[str]])
  • “outputs”: absolute paths to output files produced by the job (Dict[str, List[str]])

A complete job_descriptions has the following structure:

{
    'run': [
        {
            'id': int,
            'inputs': list or dict,
            'outputs': list or dict,
        },
        ...
        ]
    'collect':
        {
            'inputs': list or dict,
            'outputs': list or dict
        }
}
Parameters:**kwargs –

additional variable input arguments as key-value pairs
Returns:job descriptions
Return type:Dict[str, List[dict] or dict]
create_jobs(job_descriptions, virtualenv='tmaps')[source]¶

Create a GC3Pie task collection of “jobs”.

Parameters:
  • job_descriptions (Dict[List[dict]]) – description of inputs and outputs or individual jobs
  • virtualenv (str, optional) – name of a virtual environment that should be activated (defaults to "tmaps")
Returns:

jobs
Return type:

gc3libs.workflow.SequentialTaskCollection

Note

A SequentialTaskCollection is returned even if there is only one parallel task (a collection of jobs that are processed in parallel). This is done for consistency so that jobs from different steps can be handled the same way and easily be combined into a larger workflow.

See also

`get_job_descriptions_from_files`_

tmlib.cycle module¶

class tmlib.cycle.Cycle(cycle_dir, user_cfg, library)[source]¶

Bases: object

A cycle represents an individual image acquisition time point as part of a time series experiment and corresponds to a folder on disk.

The Cycle class provides attributes and methods for accessing the contents of this folder.

See also

`experiment.Experiment`_

CYCLE_DIR_FORMAT = 'cycle_{cycle_ix:0>2}'¶
STATS_FILE_FORMAT = 'channel_{channel_ix}.stat.h5'¶

Returns:name of the file that contains cycle-specific descriptions required for the alignment of images of the current cycle relative to the reference cycle
Return type:str

Returns:absolute path to the cycle folder
Return type:str
experiment¶
Returns:name of the corresponding parent experiment folder
Return type:str

Returns:absolute path to the parent experiment directory
Return type:str

Returns:names of illumination correction files in stats_dir
Return type:List[str]
Raises:OSError – when stats_dir does not exist or when no illumination statistic files are found in stats_dir

Returns:illumination statistics images for each channel
Return type:Dict[int, IllumstatsImages]

Note

Image objects have lazy loading functionality, i.e. the actual image pixel array is only loaded into memory once the corresponding attribute is accessed.

Returns:metadata for each file in image_dir in tabular form, where rows represent images and columns hold the values for different metadata attributes
Return type:pandas.DataFrame
Raises:OSError – when metadata file does not exist

Note

The table representation of metadata is cached in memory and allows efficient indexing. See pandas docs for details on indexing and selecting data.

images¶
Returns:image object for each image file in image_dir
Return type:List[ChannelImage]

Note

Image objects have lazy loading functionality, i.e. the actual image pixel array is only loaded into memory once the corresponding attribute (property) is accessed.

Raises:ValueError – when names of image files and names in the image metadata are not the same
index¶

A cycle represents a time point in a time series. The index is the zero-based index of the cycle in this sequence. It is encoded in the name of the cycle folder and is retrieved from it using a regular expression.

Returns:zero-based cycle index
Return type:int
Raises:RegexError – when index cannot not be determined from folder name
name¶
Returns:name of the cycle folder
Return type:str
plate_name¶
Returns:name of the plate to which images of this cycle belong
Return type:str
stats_dir¶
Returns:path to the directory holding illumination statistic files
Return type:str

Note

Creates the directory if it doesn’t exist.

tmlib.experiment module¶

class tmlib.experiment.Experiment(experiment_dir, user_cfg=None, library='vips')[source]¶

Bases: object

An experiment is a repository for images and associated data.

An experiment consists of one or more plates. A plate is a container for the imaged biological samples and can be associated with one or more cycles, where a cycle represents a particular time point of image acquisition. In the simplest case, an experiment is composed of a single plate with only one cycle.

The experiment and its elements are represented by directories on the file system and their locations are defined by the corresponding configuration classes.

See also

`tmlib.plate.Plate`_ `tmlib.cycle.Cycle`_

add_plate(plate_name)[source]¶

Add a plate to the experiment, i.e. create a subdirectory in plates_dir.

Raises:OSError – when the plate already exists

sources¶

An experiment consists of one or multiple plates. Each plate itself is composed of one or multiple acquisitions, which contain the actual source files.

Returns:configured plate acquisitions objects
Return type:List[tmlib.source.PlateSource]

See also

`tmlib.source.PlateSource`_

Note

All plates belonging to one experiment must have the same layout, i.e. contain the same number of image acquisition sites. However, the number of acquired images may differ between plates, for example due to a different number of channels.

sources_dir¶
Returns:absolute path to the directory, where source files (original microscope files) are located
Return type:str
Raises:OSError – when source_dir does not exist

Note

The user has to create the directory and provide its location.

user_cfg¶
Returns:experiment-specific user configuration settings
Return type:tmlib.cfg.UserConfiguration

Note

If not set, the settings are loaded from a configuration file. Its location is specified by the user_cfg_file attribute.

Raises:OSError – when value is None and configuration settings file does not exist
user_cfg_file¶
Returns:absolute path to an experiment-specific user configuration settings file
Return type:str

tmlib.formats module¶

class tmlib.formats.Formats[source]¶

Bases: object

Class for providing information on file formats supported by Bio-Formats.

SUPPORT_FOR_ADDITIONAL_FILES = set(['visiview', 'cellvoyager', 'metamorph'])¶
extract_supported_formats(input_filename, support_level=0)[source]¶

Extract names and extensions of supported formats from XML or HTML file and save them as key-value pairs in a JSON file.

The XML file can be generated via the Bio-Formats command line tool formatlist:

formatlist -xml > supported-formats.xml

The HTML file can be downloaded from the Bio-Formats website, which lists supported formats together with the level of support for each format:

wget http://www.openmicroscopy.org/site/support/bio-formats5.1/supported-formats.html
Parameters:
  • input_filename (str) – absolute path to the XML or HTML file, that specifies the supported formats
  • support_level (uint, optional) – minimum level of support for reading pixel and metadata, where 0 is no support, 1 is “poor” and 5 is “outstanding” support (Note: support information is only available for the HTML file)
Raises:

OSError – when filename does not exist
supported_extensions¶
Returns:file extensions of supported formats
Return type:Set[str]
supported_formats¶
Returns:names and file extensions of supported formats as key-value pairs
Return type:Dict[str, List[str]]

class tmlib.image.IllumstatsImage(pixels, metadata)[source]¶

Bases: object

Class for a illumination statistics image: a 2D greyscale image with a single band.

class tmlib.image.IllumstatsImages[source]¶

Bases: object

Class that serves as a container for illumination statistics images.

It provides the mean and standard deviation matrices for a given channel. The statistics are calculated at each pixel position over all image sites acquired in the same channel [1].

References

[1]Stoeger T, Battich N, Herrmann MD, Yakimovich Y, Pelkmans L. 2015. Computer vision for image-based transcriptomics. Methods.
static create_from_file(filename, metadata=None, library='vips')[source]¶

  • metadata (IllumstatsMetadata) – metadata object
  • library (str, optional) – image library that should be used, “vips” or “numpy” (defaults to “vips”)
Returns:

container for IllumstatsImage objects
Return type:

IllumstatsImages

class tmlib.image.Image[source]¶

Bases: object

Abstract base class for an image, which represents a 2D pixels array.

2D means that the image doesn’t contain any z-stacks. However, the image array may still have more than 2 dimensions. The 3rd dimension represents color and is referred to as “bands”.

The class provides the image pixel array as well as associated metadata. It makes use of lazy loading so that image objects can be created without the pixels arrays being immediately loaded into memory.

filename¶
Returns:absolute path to the image file
Return type:str
metadata¶
Returns:metadata object
Return type:Metadata

See also

`tmlib.metadata.ImageMetadata`_

pixels¶
save_as_png(filename)[source]¶

Write image to disk as PNG file.

Parameters:filename (str) – absolute path to output file
class tmlib.image.MaskImage[source]¶

Parameters:crop (bool, optional) – whether images should cropped or rather padded with zero valued pixels (default: True)
Returns:aligned image
Return type:MaskImage

Warning

Alignment may change the dimensions of the image when crop is True.

  • library (str, optional) – image library that should be used, “vips” or “numpy” (defaults to “vips”)

class tmlib.image.SegmentationImage[source]¶

Bases: tmlib.image.Image

Class for a labeled image: a 2D segmentation image, where each object (connected component) is labeled with a unique identifier. The labeling can be encoded in a single band or in multiple bands (which may become necessary when the number of objects exceeds the depth

of the image, e.g. a greyscale 16-bit image one only encode 2^16 objects).
align(crop=True)[source]¶

Align, i.e. shift and crop, an image based on calculated shift and overhang values.

Parameters:crop (bool, optional) – whether images should cropped or rather padded with zero valued pixels (default: True)
Returns:aligned image
Return type:SegmentationImage

Warning

Alignment may change the dimensions of the image when crop is True.

static create_from_file(filename, metadata, library='vips')[source]¶

Create a SegmentationImage object from a file on disk.

Parameters:
  • filename (str) – absolute path to the image file
  • metadata (SegmentationImageMetadata) – image metadata object
  • library (str, optional) – image library that should be used, “vips” or “numpy” (defaults to “vips”)
Returns:

image object
Return type:

SegmentationImage
Raises:

tmlib.image_readers module¶

tmlib.image_utils module¶

tmlib.image_utils.calc_threshold_level(sample_images, percent=99.9)[source]¶

Calculate threshold level for a particular quantile across a set of sample images.

A top threshold percentage of 99.9 would mean that 0.1% of the pixels with the largest value should be set to their lowest value.

The quantile above threshold_top_percent pixels is computed for each image in sample_images and then averaged.

Parameters:
  • sample_images (List[Vips.Image[Vips.BandFormat.USHORT]]) – images that are representative of the images that are to be thresholded
  • top_percent (float, optional) – quantile (default: 99.9)
Returns:

threshold level
Return type:

int
tmlib.image_utils.convert_to_uint8(img)[source]¶

Convert a 16-bit image to 8-bit by linearly scaling from 0-max(img) to 0-255.

This can be useful for the display of an image in a figure.

Parameters:image (numpy.ndarray[uint16]) –
Returns:
Return type:numpy.ndarray[uint8]

Note

This is equivalent to Image > Type > 8-bit in ImageJ.

tmlib.image_utils.create_spacer_image(height, width, dtype, bands)[source]¶

Create a black image that can be inserted as a spacer between channel images.

Parameters:
  • height (int) – dimension of the image in y dimension
  • width (int) – dimension of the image in x dimension
  • dtype (Vips.BandFormat) – data type (format) of the image
  • bands (int) – number of color dimensions (1 for grayscale and 3 for RGB)
Returns:

black image of specified dtype
Return type:

Vips.Image
tmlib.image_utils.create_thresholding_LUT(threshold)[source]¶

Construct a 16 bit color lookup table that can be used to threshold images.

The computed lookup table will set any values above a threshold level to that threshold level.

Parameters:threshold (int) – threshold level
Returns:LUT (= 1 x 2^16 pixel Vips image)
Return type:Vips.Image

Examples

The LUT can be used like this:

lut = create_thresholding_LUT(some_images, 0.1)
thresholded_img = img.maplut(lut)  # apply to some image

Parameters:im (numpy.ndarray) – label image
Returns:1 if object represent a border object and 0 otherwise
Return type:List[int]

Bases: logging.Filter

filter(record)[source]¶
tmlib.logging_utils.configure_logging(level)[source]¶

Create a logger instance and configure it for the command line applications.

Two stream handlers will be added to the logger:
  • “out” that will direct INFO & DEBUG messages to the standard output

stream * “err” that will direct WARN, WARNING, ERROR, & CRITICAL messages to the standard error stream

Parameters:level (int) – logging level verbosity
Returns:configured logger object
Return type:logging.Logger

Warning

Logging should only be configured at the main entry point of the application, but not within the library!

tmlib.logging_utils.map_logging_verbosity(verbosity)[source]¶
Parameters:verbosity (int) – logging verbosity level (0-4)
Returns:
  • Returns a logging level as exported by logging module.
  • By default returns logging.NOTSET

class tmlib.metadata.ImageFileMapper[source]¶

Bases: object

Container for information about the location of individual images (planes) within the original image file and references to the files in which they will be stored upon extraction.

PERSISTENT_ATTRS = set(['files', 'ref_file', 'series', 'planes', 'ref_id', 'ref_index'])¶
__iter__()[source]¶
Returns:key-value representation of the object (only PERSISTENT_ATTRS attributes)
Return type:dict

Examples

>>>obj = ImageFileMapper() >>>obj.series = [0, 0] >>>obj.planes = [0, 1] >>>obj.files = [“a”, “b”] >>>obj.ref_index = 0 >>>obj.ref_file = “c” >>>obj.ref_id = “Image:0” >>>dict(obj) {‘series’: [0, 0], ‘planes’: [0, 1], ‘ref_id’: ‘Image:0’, ‘ref_index’: 0, ‘filenames’: [‘a’, ‘b’], ‘ref_name’: ‘c’}

files¶
Returns:absolute path to the required original image files
Return type:str
planes¶
Returns:zero-based position index of the required planes in the original file
Return type:int
ref_file¶
Returns:absolute path to the final image file
Return type:List[str]
ref_id¶
Returns:identifier string of the image in the configured OMEXML (pattern: (Image:S+)); e.g. “Image:0”)
Return type:List[str]
ref_index¶
Returns:index of the image in the image Series in the OMEXML
Return type:List[str]
series¶
Returns:zero-based position index of the required series in the original file
Return type:int
static set(description)[source]¶
Parameters:description (dict) – key-value representation of the object
Returns:object where PERSISTENT_ATTRS attributes where set with provided values
Return type:ImageFileMapper
class tmlib.metadata.ImageMetadata[source]¶

Bases: object

Base class for image metadata, such as the name of the channel or the relative position of the image within the acquisition grid.

PERSISTENT_ATTRS = set(['site_ix', 'id', 'tpoint_ix', 'zplane_ix', 'name'])¶
id¶
Returns:zero-based unique image identifier number
Return type:int
is_aligned¶
Returns:indicates whether the image has been aligned
Return type:bool
is_omitted¶
Returns:whether the image should be omitted from further analysis (for example because the shift exceeds the maximally tolerated
shift or because the image contains artifacts)
Return type:bool
left_overhang¶
Returns:overhang in pixels at the left side of the image relative to the corresponding image in the reference cycle
Return type:int
lower_overhang¶
Returns:overhang in pixels at the lower side of the image relative to the corresponding image in the reference cycle
Return type:int
name¶
Returns:name of the image (the same as the name of the corresponding file on disk)
Return type:str
plate_name¶
Returns:name of the plate to which the image belongs
Return type:str
right_overhang¶
Returns:overhang in pixels at the right side of the image relative to the corresponding image in the reference cycle
Return type:int
site_ix¶
Returns:zero-based global (plate-wide) acquisition-site index
Return type:int

Note

The index doesn’t follow any particular order, it just indicates which images where acquired at the same “site”, i.e. microscope stage position.

tpoint_ix¶
Returns:one-based time point identifier number
Return type:int
upper_overhang¶
Returns:overhang in pixels at the upper side of the image relative to the corresponding image in the reference cycle
Return type:int
well_name¶
Returns:well identifier string, e.g. “A01”
Return type:str
well_pos_x¶
Returns:zero-based column (x) index of the image within the well
Return type:int
well_pos_y¶
Returns:zero-based row (y) index of the image within the well
Return type:int
x_shift¶
Returns:shift of the image in pixels in x direction relative to the corresponding image in the reference cycle
Return type:int
y_shift¶
Returns:shift of the image in pixels in y direction relative to the corresponding image in the reference cycle
Return type:int
zplane_ix¶
Returns:zero-based z index of the focal plane within a three dimensional stack
Return type:int

tmlib.mosaic module¶

class tmlib.mosaic.Collage(array)[source]¶

Bases: tmlib.mosaic.StichedImage

static create_from_images(images, dx=100, dy=100, stats=None, shift=None)[source]¶

Create a Collage object from image objects.

Parameters:
  • images (List[ChannelImage]) – set of images that are all of the same cycle and channel
  • dx (int, optional) – displacement in x direction in pixels, i.e. gap that should be introduced between individual images in x direction (positive integer value; default: 100)
  • dy (int, optional) – displacement in y direction in pixels, i.e. gap that should be introduced between individual images in y direction (positive integer value; default: 100)
  • stats (IllumstatsImages, optional) – illumination statistics to correct images for illumination artifacts
  • shift (List[ShiftDescription], optional) – shift descriptions, when provided images are aligned between cycles
Returns:
Return type:

Mosaic
Raises:
  • ValueError – when dx or dy are negative
  • MetadataError – when images are not of same cycle or channel
  • TypeError – when images are not of the same data type
class tmlib.mosaic.Mosaic(array)[source]¶

Bases: tmlib.mosaic.StichedImage

Class for a mosaic image of type Vips.Image.

static create_from_images(images, dx=0, dy=0, stats=None, shift=False)[source]¶

Create a Mosaic object from image objects.

Parameters:
  • images (List[ChannelImage]) – set of images that are all of the same cycle and channel
  • dx (int, optional) – displacement in x direction in pixels; i.e. overlap of images in x direction (negative integer value; default: 0)
  • dy (int, optional) – displacement in y direction in pixels; i.e. overlap of images in y direction (negative integer value; default: 0)
  • stats (IllumstatsImages, optional) – illumination statistics to correct images for illumination artifacts
  • shift (bool, optional) – whether images should be aligned between cycles
Returns:
Return type:

Mosaic
Raises:

ValueError – when dx or dy are positive

tmlib.readers module¶

class tmlib.readers.BioformatsImageReader(directory=None)[source]¶

Bases: tmlib.readers.ImageReader

Class for reading images using the Bio-Formats library.

Note

Requires a running Java Virtual Machine (VM). This is achieved via the javabridge package.

Warning

Once the VM is killed it cannot be started again. This means that a second call of this class will fail.

Examples

>>> filename = '/path/to/image/file'
>>> with BioformatsImageReader() as reader:
...     img = reader.read(filename)
>>> type(img)
numpy.ndarray
read(filename)[source]¶

Read an image from a file on disk.

For details on reading images via Bio-Format from Python, see load_image().

Unfortunately, the documentation is very sparse and sometimes wrong. If you need additional information, refer to the relevant source code.

Parameters:

filename (str) – absolute path to the image file
Raises:
  • OSError – when filename does not exist
  • NotSupportedError – when the file format is not supported by the reader
Returns:

pixel array
Return type:

numpy.ndarray
read_subset(filename, series=None, plane=None)[source]¶

Read a subset of images from a file on disk.

Parameters:
  • filename (str) – absolute path to the image file
  • series (int, optional) – zero-based series index (only relevant if the file contains more than one Image elements)
  • plane (int, optional) –

    zero-based plane index within a series (only relevant if Image elements within the file contain

    more than one Plane element)
Returns:

2D pixel array
Return type:

numpy.ndarray
Raises:
  • OSError – when filename does not exist
  • NotSupportedError – when the file format is not supported by the reader

read(filename, **kwargs)[source]¶

Read JSON file.

  • filename (str) – path to the JSON file
  • **kwargs –

    additional arguments as key-value pairs (none implemented)

file content

dict or list

filename can be provided as relative path when directory was set upon instantiation of the reader object.

Raises:OSError – when filename does not exist
class tmlib.readers.MetadataReader(directory=None)[source]¶

Bases: tmlib.readers.Reader

Abstract base class for reading metadata from additional (non-image) files.

They return metadata as OMEXML objects, according to the OME data model, see python-bioformats.

Unfortunately, the documentation is very sparse. If you need additional information, refer to the relevant source code.

Note

In case custom readers provide a Plate element, they also have to specify an ImageRef elements for each WellSample element, which serve as references to OME Image elements. Each ImageRef attribute must be a dictionary with a single entry. The value must be a list of strings, where each element represents the reference information that can be used to map the WellSample element to an individual Image element. The key must be a regular expression string that can be used to extract the reference information from the corresponding image filenames.

read(filename)[source]¶
class tmlib.readers.NumpyImageReader(directory=None)[source]¶

Bases: tmlib.readers.ImageReader

Class for reading images from files on disk as numpy arrays.

Uses the OpenCV library.

Examples

>>> filename = '/path/to/image/file'
>>> with NumpyImageReader() as reader:
...     img = reader.read(filename)
>>> type(img)
numpy.ndarray

read_subset(filename, series=None, plane=None)[source]¶

If the image file contains more than one plane (band), only the first one will be read.

class tmlib.readers.OpenslideImageReader(directory=None)[source]¶

Bases: tmlib.readers.SlideReader

Class for reading whole slide images and associated metadata using the Openslide library.

Raises:NotSupportedError – when the file format is not supported by the reader

Warning

Openslide doesn’t support fluorescence slides.

Examples

>>> filename = '/path/to/image/file'
>>> with OpenslideReader() as reader:
...     img = reader.read(filename)
>>> type(img)
Vips.Image

tmlib.readers.logger = <logging.Logger object>¶

Reader classes.

All readers make use of the with statement context manager. and follow a similar syntax:

with Reader('/path/to/folder') as reader:
    data = reader.read('name_of_file')

with Reader() as reader:
    data = reader.read('/path/to/file')

tmlib.utils.missing_elements(data, start=None, end=None)[source]¶

Determine missing elements in a sequence of integers.

Parameters:
  • data (List[int]) – sequence with potentially missing elements
  • start (int, optional) – lower limit of the range (defaults to 0)
  • end (int, optional) – upper limit of the range (defaults to len(data)-1)

Examples

>>>data = [10, 12, 13, 15, 16, 19, 20] >>>list(missing_elements(data)) [11, 14, 17, 18]

tmlib.utils.regex_from_format_string(format_string)[source]¶

Convert a format string of the sort “{name}_bla/something_{number}” to a named regular expression a la “P<name>.*_bla/something_P<number>d+”.

Parameters:format_string (str) – Python format string
Returns:named regular expression pattern
Return type:str
